DOC.HEAD: Radicals Capture Parliament Seats In Elections
DOC.TEXT: Anti-Western radicals have won several parliamentary seats in special elections, strengthening hard-line opposition to President Hashemi Rafsanjani's policy of economic reform. The official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, reported late Saturday that former Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a middle-ranking cleric, took 225,570 votes in polling to win from a Tehran district. Another hard-line cleric, Hojatoleslam Movahedi Kermani, also was elected Friday in Tehran with 287,921 votes, IRNA reported. Diplomats said the mid-term elections were seen as a test for Rafsanjani's policies. Sixty-four candidates ran in the elections, called to fill nine vacant seats in the 270-member Parliament. Iran's official media reported a heavy turnout but gave no overall figures. Most of the seats were left empty when Rafsanjani appointed legislators to his Cabinet following his election July 28. Tehran Radio said four other candidates, including lesser-known radicals, won seats in provincial centers. The state radio, also monitored in Nicosia, said no candidate won a majority in two other Tehran districts and the provincial Bandar Turkman constituency, so a second round of voting will be held. The front-runners for the remaining Tehran seats are all radicals _ former Commerce Minister Habibollah Asgarowladi, former Labor Minister Aboloasem Sarhadizadeh and former Posts and Telegraphs Minister Morteza Nabavi. Mohtashemi's election marked a comeback for the 43-year-old Islamic fundamentalist, who has close links with pro-Iranian militants holding Western hostages in Lebanon. Rafsanjani, leader of Tehran's so-called pragmatists, dumped Mohtashemi and other hard-liners in August, when he formed a Cabinet dominated by technocrats designed to revitalize Iran's economy following last year's cease-fire in the eight-year war with Iraq. Mohtashemi is allied with Ahmad Khomeini, son of the late revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and considered a focal point for the radicals espousing the ayatollah's ideological legacy. The hard-liners oppose Rafsanjani's moves to improve Iran's relations with the West to acquire badly needed investment to help the post-war economy. They contend his policies move too far from the fundamentalist principles that form the bedrock of the 1979 Islamic revolution. Rafsanjani, while no less committed to the revolution than his rivals, believes Iran cannot afford to remain isolated and that its 55 million people have had enough hardship after a decade of turmoil and war. Radicals already dominate the Majlis and their gains are likely to further inhibit Rafsanjani's room for maneuver between guiding Iran into a more open, prosperous era while preserving Islamic principles.
